III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The Anderson Life Development Center (ALDC) program is located on the westside
of Detroit near Livernois and Tireman streets. The building is a large two-story 6,262
square footage building. The building was originally a part of the Church of God &
Christ. In 2018 the church sold the building to an investment company, the
Foundation of Life and Praise Church. ALDC has leased this property from this
company since 2020. The building currently serves as a host home for older teen
girls and their babies/toddlers. ALDC is seeking to become licensed to be able to
provide independent living services to this clientele and others directly.
The Ohio street location will serve as the agency’s home office and living facility for
at least 12-13 female youths to whom the program will be licensed to serve. The
building is spacious, with two furnished offices on the first level, with space for a third
2

when needed, along with a large living room, playroom with toys and play pens,
dining room/classroom, kitchen, one bathroom, one storage room for things like
strollers, and one emergency bedroom to accommodate an emergency placement.
All of the rooms on this first level are fully furnished with equipment or living items,
like a desk and a chair for the offices, a large dining table and chairs for the dining
room, sofas and chair for the living room, and full-size bed, dresser, and book shelf
for the bedroom. All the items in the respective rooms are functional. The kitchen
has lots of storage area, counters, and cabinet space. Each youth can have their
own storage cabinet. There are three refrigerators, and one freezer in the kitchen.
The second level of the building has four bathrooms, two linen closets, 12
bedrooms; nine of which are fully carpeted. Each bedroom has a door for privacy
and contains either a twin or full side bed, with a crib or toddler bed, a desk, dresser,
chair or rocker and television. Each bed contains linen, which is provided by the
agency. The basement of the building contains two washers, and two dryers for the
youths’ usage.
Overall, the building is semi-modernly furnished, and it has clear emergency exits,
and two security cameras on the first level. No cameras are located in a bedroom or
bathroom. The building is location in a residential area, near public transportation,
stores, and other community resources. There is parking available for clients, visitors
and staff in front of the building.
B. Program Description
The agency will provide independent living (IL) services that includes general
independent living, independent living-plus, and independent living -plus parental
assistance for clients with an infant or toddler. The youths are age 16 to 21 females
and males who are homeless, in foster care, aging out of foster care or have a
juvenile justice case and requires or can benefit from some type of supportive
independent living assistance. The Ohio address will only serve female youths, and
the agency will seek to serve male youths via community host homes in the near
future. The agency will take referrals from the department, child placement
agencies, volunteer referrals, and will work with other IL programs, and agencies to
support and assist the youth. The youth will receive a Daniel Memorial Assessment
and interview to determine their readiness for independent living. Youths referred
from residential programs must show signs of emotional and mental health
improvement and stability prior to acceptance in this program. Youths with suicidal
ideations and or a history of suicidal attempts, and youths with special diagnoses,
such as oppositional defiant disorder, bipolar or schizophrenia will be evaluated and
accepted on a case-by-case basis.
Youths in independent living, independent living plus, and independent living plus
with parental assistance will receive an array of services including case
management, education and job assistance, life skill training and support as needed.
Youths in the ALDC can live onsite at the staffed program on Ohio Street, in a
hosted home, or on their own in the community. The youth will receive a stipend
3

from the state, which ALDC will assist the youth in learning to budget. Youths will
also receive parenting education and assistance as needed to aid them in learning
parenting skills.
The agency’s policies and procedures have been reviewed and have been found to
be compliant with rules and statutes. The agency will operate with a chief
administrator, license designee, who will initially serve as the case work supervisor,
and a case manager. Additionally, the program will employ a House Manager, who
will reside onsite and work from 7:00pm to 7:00 am and House Monitors/Youth
Specialists who will provide support and supervision to youths from 3:00pm 7: 00am.
A second case manager and youth specialist supervisor to oversee the house
monitors/youth specialist will be hired once the program is licensed and more youths
are accepted/placed. The program will also employ a Life skills Coach/Advocate who
will work with youth in IL- plus on daily life and personal development needs and
goals. If youths are in need of therapeutic services the agency will offer/provide a
linkage via Zoe counseling services in Southfield, Michigan or it will aid the youth in
finding other counseling or mental health services as needed or desired.
The agency is a 501(c)(3) approved corporation. It provided seven letters of
references as well as a projected budget for the program which illustrated its
potential to meet the program’s projected financial needs.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
At this time, there are no rule violations.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The issuance of an original license for a private child placing agency for purpose
of providing independent living services is recommended at this time.
